unnormalised: Okay, so you're going through a divorce? It's tough, I know. Family law in India can feel like navigating a maze, esp. when emotions are running high. Let's talk about some things, yeah? This isn't legal advice, mind you, just some friendly info to get you started. Think of it as chai and chit-chat before you meet Adv. Sharma.

unnormalised: First off, there's the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Divorce) Act, 1986, and the Special Marriage Act, 1954. Which one applies to you depends on your religion and how you got married, right? Seems obvious, but trust me, many folks get confused. If you had a court marriage in Delhi, probably the SMA. Knowing this at least gives your lawyer a head start!
normalised: First off, there's the Hindu Marriage Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty five, the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Divorce) Act, one thousand nine hundred and eighty six, and the Special Marriage Act, one thousand nine hundred and fifty four. Which one applies to you depends on your religion and how you got married, right? Seems obvious, but trust me, many folks get confused. If you had a court marriage in Delhi, probably the S-M-A. Knowing this at least gives your lawyer a head start!

unnormalised: Then there's the whole issue of alimony. How much will the wife get? How much can the husband realistically pay? This is where things get sticky. Some courts order a lump sum – say, ₹20,00,000 – while others go for monthly payments, maybe Rs. 25,000/- per month. It all depends on factors like the husband's income, the wife's earning potential (or lack thereof), and the length of the marriage. BTW, the courts usually consider 1/3rd of the husband’s net income as a reasonable benchmark for alimony.

Some courts order a lump sum – say, rupee twenty lakh – while others go for monthly payments, maybe rupees twenty five thousand per month. It all depends on factors like the husband's income, the wife's earning potential (or lack thereof), and the length of the marriage. By the way, the courts usually consider one third of the husband's net income as a reasonable benchmark for alimony.

unnormalised: Child custody is another biggie. Who gets the kids? Usually, the mother gets primary custody, esp. if the children are young. But the father still gets visitation rights, usually on weekends or during holidays. Say, every 2nd & 4th Saturday. Courts want what’s best for the kids, you see. The legal jargon here can get complicated; terms like “guardian of the person” and "guardian of the property" are quite common.

unnormalised: And what about the house? Who gets to stay in it? If it's jointly owned, the court might order it to be sold and the proceeds divided. If it's in the husband's name, the wife might have to find a new place to live, unless the court orders otherwise, maybe due to medical or welfare reasons. Property division is often a significant point of contention, and can often take multiple hearings, say, >5, until an agreement is reached.

unnormalised: Remember, every case is unique. What worked for Priya's divorce in Mumbai might not work for Rakesh's in Bangalore. Don't rely solely on what you read online, including this! Get professional advice. Find a good family lawyer, Adv. someone good. Look at lawyers with 10+ years of experience, esp. if children are involved.
